awd_titl_txt: Model Predictive Control with Discrete/Continuous Decisions: Theory, Computation, and Application
awd_abstract_narration:
1603768 PI: Rawlings
Title: Model Predictive Control with Discrete/Continuous Decisions: Theory, Computation, and Application

Systems requiring online discrete operating decisions, also known as actuators in the control context, are ubiquitous. In the historical development of feedback control theory relevant to process control, however, the discrete decisions were always removed from the online control problem and considered at a different level in the automation system, often using heuristic rules, such as cycling through some bank of furnaces or chillers in a pre-specified order. As a result, optimization of these discrete decisions has seen essentially no implementation in process control applications, while optimization of the continuous decisions (valve positions, applied voltages, torques, etc.) has reached a high level, as demonstrated by the widespread use of model predictive control (MPC) in the process industries. The goal of this research project is to enable optimization and feedback control of processes that have discrete as well as continuous decision variables. The PI proposes to develop both new theory and computational software to address this class of problems. The research will be conducted in close collaboration with an industrial partner, Johnson Controls, and the research results will be tested in applications involving control of heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems in commercial buildings. Energy use in buildings is responsible for a significant fraction of energy consumption and carbon emissions in the US.

The proposed new theory encompasses both nominal closed-loop stability and inherent robustness to model errors and disturbances, and requires extension of standard MPC with continuous decisions (valve positions, applied voltages, torques, etc.) to MPC with both continuous and discrete variables (on/off switches for chillers, heaters, pumps; which equipment to use when during a periodic, cyclic operation, etc.). The proposed project aims to develop: (i) new theory for MPC with discrete/continuous actuators, (ii) new free-source software to solve the MPC control problem with discrete actuators, and (iii) an approach for decomposing the large-scale, complex building HVAC control problem into tractable sub-problems. The enabling computational software will be made available to all researchers in the free-source language CasADi, which has become the leading language for solving large, complex, and structured optimal control problems. Adding discrete decision variables to CasADi will provide practitioners with a tool to implement the results of this research in a broad range of industrial applications. The PI plans to train a graduate student and develop new educational materials on control system design.

por.por_cntn:
This award addressed the challenge of optimizing in realtime the energy use in large-scale commercial buildings or campuses of many buildings.  At the start of the grant period, this challenge could not be met with available technology.  The dynamic model is nonlinear, has discrete as well as continuous decision variables, large scale, and stochastic (weather and electricity prices).  The feedback measurement is large dimensional and noisy. The optimization solution is required in realtime (minutes) and must be robust against numerical failure.

The main two outcomes of this award are that: (i) today this technology does exist and (ii) it has already been deployed on several university campuses, including the 155-building Stanford campus.

Modeling. We have shown how to optimize building heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) equipment as a mixed-integer linear programming model. The developed linear programming model enables fast and robust online optimization of the water-side HVAC problem. This result was published in Energy Buildings.

Theory.  We have established the supporting theory for optimizing the discrete actuators within a model predictive control (MPC) framework. The theory that extended the closed-loop properties of MPC to cover this class of new problems appeared in Automatica, one of the leading journals for systems theory.

Researchers and industrial practitioners have been given the theoretical and computational tools to implement the methods developed in this research across a wide variety of industrial sectors, and specifically in energy optimization in commercial buildings and campuses of buildings.  We have provided freely available software (CasADi and MPCTools) for numerical implementation of this new version of model predictive control. (Image 1)

Implementation. Working with commercial vendor Johnson Controls, Inc., we have collaborated in the development of commercialized products to deploy these systems in large collections of buildings such as university campuses and industrial research and development centers.

Education.  The new results on discrete actuators, economic MPC, and computational software have been incorporated in the recently completed second edition of our MPC textbook, "Model Predictive Control: Theory, Computation, and Design, 2nd ed."  We add a chapter, "Chapter 8, Numerical Optimal Control," and co-author, Professor Moritz Diehl, of the University of Freiburg. (Image 2)

We also created a case study problem definition loosely based on an industrial application at Stanford University (depicted above). This case study is made publicly available for other researchers in the HVAC community to provide a standardized problem for the research community to design and test the performance and viability various control systems. (Image 3)

Broader impacts.  Optimizing a high-level objective such as profit over discrete as well as continuous decisions is a fundamental task in automatic control, and can be applied to many processes including manufacturing, routing, guidance, navigation, etc.
